bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, February 23, 1916

div1.p: LePrince discusses the recovery of marked mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, February 23, 1916
div1.p:
I received your letter of Feb 16
and turned the two papers over to Dr
von Ezdorf, asking him to return them
to me to return to you, but understand
he has sent them back to you yesterday-

Two days was the shortest period, 4
mosquitoes were retaken after being
stained distance traveled 1,500, to 4800 ft- However we must consider
the speed with which they traveled
and the chances of missing the
stained ones- Of the thousands
stained in 18 days (say about 25000) only a small
number were recovered- During
the days of staining operations periods
1 to 5 days occurred when no stained
specimens were captured- If 3000
were stained on one night & some of them went
to Gatun with millions of unstained
ones & the width of flight path was
5340
2
one half mile wide the chances of
recapture is small unless a large
number of men are used to recapture.

Those that were taken at 6250 ft
at Col Sihuts house marked with Eosin
were captured on Feb 11th but eosion
was used Jan 27 to Feb 5, & Feb 11, and
How many did not fly we do
not know-

Fourteen days after staining was
stopped a stained specimen was found
in the swamp near liberation station- If
“Quimby plates” were used on
return flight. It might be possible
to pick up some stained specimens
on the return flight- There are many
things yet to be determined- I am
convinced that some of the return
flight are stopped by daylight, & dont
complete the return earlier than
the next day- I doubt that the
3
forward flight is of two days duration
except in very few cases- I think
they travel a mile in a half
hour or less in a continuous trip.
I cant prove it anymore than I
could prove the flight against the
wind when I was sure such
was the case- But I think future
experimental will show it to be true.

About the blood supply question
for quads here- I am not sure
yet that the larvae will not
be found in large numbers
away from humans & domestic
animals-. If it is so with aedes
in the Klondike, with culex in
uninhabited sections of our seacoast
region- Why not under favorable
conditions with some of the anopheles-
I believe that blood helps a heap
& that anopheles gett more numerous
near a favorable food supply
but I have not examined
sufficient suitable areas
in uninhabited territory, say
two miles away from houses &
used roads, pastures etc to be
quite sure - as to have much blood
they get aside from humans & cattle. And I
think this question needs investi
gation-.
